Award.AwardTitle: Nitric oxide as cell-intrinsic messenger of neuronal function
Award.AbstractNarration: The long-term goal of this project is to identify the role of the gaseous neuronal messenger molecule Nitric oxide (NO) in the development of the nervous system. NO is known to be involved in a large number of physiological events and in most of these cases, NO is released by one cell or tissue and then acts on another cell or tissue. The possibility that NO might also have physiological effects in the cell in which it is produced, however, has attracted very little attention so far. Novel preliminary evidence shows that NO can have important physiological roles within cells that produce it, such as regulating a variety of ion channels and determining the speed with which nerve cells grow. During neuronal development, the motile tips of advancing neuronal structures, called growth cones, guide extending nerve processes (such as axons and dendrites) to their appropriate targets by a process termed pathfinding. Expression of the Nitric Oxide Synthase (NOS) gene, which is responsible for the enzymatic production of NO, has been linked to the process of synapse formation and neuronal plasticity, making the neuronal growth cone a prime location for NO to act and effect pathfinding and synaptogenesis. Techniques used in this study include electrophysiology, molecular biology, cell culture and advanced imaging applications. The research proposed will provide the groundwork to refine our thinking about NO signaling in the brain and will serve as the basis to develop novel approaches to investigate brain development and repair. The proposed work combines research and educational components. It contains projects particularly suited for undergraduate students, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. Several successful programs at Georgia State University serve as pipelines to enhance the representation of underrepresented ethnic minorities in research laboratories and in the scientific community as a whole.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the formation of nervous systems, cell bodies of neurons grow fine processes, which elongate over time and can extend far from the cell bodies, where they make connections, termed synapses, with other nerve cells. The growing processes are guided by structures located at their tips, called growth cones. On the path to their target, growth cones interact with various signaling molecules, integrate the information received, and then use it to help them grow and find their appropriate targets. This sequence of events is somewhat recapitulated after transection of nerve fiber tracts following traumatic injury to the nervous system, where growth cones attempt to reconnect with previous targets and restore functionality to pre-injury conditions.

The research performed in this proposal had the goal to better understand the roles played by one particular signaling molecule, Nitric oxide (NO), during the development of the nervous system and during its repair after injury. NO is produced by different cell types in the nervous system, and differs from other signaling molecules by the fact that it is a gas and a radical. As such, membranes surrounding cells do not constitute a barrier, because NO can diffuse across membranes and act on multiple targets within cells. The model system used in this study was the fresh water snail Helisoma trivolvis, whose nervous system is less complex than that of vertebrates and whose nerve cells are much larger, facilitating certain types of experimentation.

The research showed that NO affects nerve cells in a cell type-specific fashion by modulating a variety of intracellular targets, ranging from ion channels to enzyme activities. Collectively, the effects of NO result in the modulation of the speed at which growth cones advance, as well as their overall shape, which, in turn, affect their ability to obtain information from the environment. These effects are mediated to a large extent by changes in the intracellular concentration of calcium ions, which serve as an important second messenger molecule and determine a host of cellular responses. The research investigated the biological signaling cascades through which NO exerts its effects and identified distinct ion channels in cell membranes that are controlled by NO and change fundamental cellular properties, such as their electrical properties, which are necessary for conveying information within and between nerve cells in the nervous system. Using molecules that release NO and testing its effects on nerve cells, the research indicates NO as a powerful modulator of neuronal excitability. Another novel finding of this research is that nerve cells that produce NO within themselves rely on the NO they produce for normal cellular function. This is different from the established view of the action of NO, where NO is produced in one cell type to act on another cell type located nearby.

In summary, the research performed improves our understanding of the roles of NO signaling during development and repair of the nervous system and provides points of intervention that might prove helpful in future studies directed at improving nervous system regeneration after injury and understanding the wiring of the nervous system during development. The funded research also resulted in the training of several undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral researchers. The work was published in peer-reviewed journals of the profession and research results were disseminated at various meetings and conferences nationally and internationally.
